data.name: Appellation
data.value: An appellation is a legally designated geographical area in which a wine originates. Most countries have their own appellation system(s); for example one system in Italy Denominazione di Origine Controllata (DOC) designation.

data.name: Bordeaux
data.value: Red Bordeaux wines are broadly classified according to which bank of the Gironde estuary the wine is made. Left Bank Bordeauxs tend to be more powerful and expensive than Right Bank.

data.name: ChateauMargaux1787
data.value: Chateau Margaux (1787) is perhaps the world's most expensive bottle of wine ever broken. Insured for $225,000, it was smashed in 1989 at a party when a waiter accidentally bumped into it.

data.name: CodeofHammurabi
data.value: The Code of Hammurabi (1,720 BC) forbid the selling of diluted alcohol. The offense was punishable by being thrown into a body of water to drown.

data.name: RedWineAntioxidants
data.value: Red wine is a good source of the antioxidant resveratrol (which helps prevent cell damage) and may be beneficial for heart health when consumed in moderation.

data.name: RedWineChemicals
data.value: Red wine contains at least 800 - 1000 different chemical compounds; and some of the most important when discussing wine are tannins, anthocyanins, and flavonols.

data.name: RomanWine
data.value: The ancient Roman's saw wine as a daily necessity to be consumed by people of all social classes. It was even prescribed to cure depression and bodily ailments.

data.name: SuperTuscans
data.value: The term "Super Tuscans" originated in the 1970s when winemakers in Italy were forced to break away from government (DOC) standards, which restricted them from using certain grapes and techniques needed to create high quality wines.

data.name: Tastevin
data.value: A tastevin is the small, silver, saucer-like cup that sommeliers traditionally used to taste and evaluate wine. Today some sommeliers still use them and carry them around their necks on a ribbon.

data.name: Toasting
data.value: The term "toasting" may have originated with the 16th century practice of placing toasted bread in wine to reduce acidity and improve flavor. The term eventually came to encompass the libations and honors that surround the beverage.

data.name: Vatican
data.value: More wine is drunk per person in the Vatican than any other country in the world (the Vatican technically being its own country).

data.name: WineAgingTemp
data.value: Most wine is ideally stored and aged at 13 °C (55 °F) with a relative humidity of 70%.

data.name: WineColor
data.value: The color of wine comes from the skin (exocarp) of the grapes, not the juice. How long the skins come into contact with the must (maceration) will effect color. Interestingly, white wine can be made from red grapes if quickly pressed.

data.name: WineStorage
data.value: Wine bottles should be stored laying sideways or even upside down, but never upright. Storing bottles standing up can cause corks to dry out and crack exposing the wine to air.

data.name: WineTrick
data.value: In a 2001 study by Frédéric Brochet, wine experts were tricked into perceiving white wine as red wine, simply by dying it red.

data.name: YoungRedHealthier
data.value: Younger red wine may be healthier for you than older vintages since some of the health promoting compounds can break down over time.
